newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish anti-monopoly body probes telecom firm TPSA.
newsitem.headline: Polish anti-monopoly body probes telecom firm TPSA.

text.p: The Polish government's Anti-Monopoly Office has launched anti-trust proceedings against state-owned telecommunications company TPSA, the office's spokeswoman said on Monday.
The proceedings, initiated late last month, concern TPSA's decision to charge higher fees for its subsidiary, Centertel SA, to use its group telecommunications facilities, the spokeswoman said.
"On August 27, 1996, proceedings were initiated in connection with alleged monopolist practices by Telekomunikacja Polska SA (TPSA)," Jolanta Micel-Thor told Reuters.
The proceedings could lead to a ruling by a special anti-monopoly court, which may fine TPSA and order it to discontinue its actions.

TPSA is in conflict with Centertel's foreign partners -- France Telecom and Ameritech Corp, which have a privileged position on the company's boards, although they hold only 24.4 percent of its shares each.
For more than a year TPSA has been seeking more say in Centertel's management and a bigger share in the company's profits -- goals opposed by the foreign shareholders.

In the latest run-in, TPSA has cancelled its agreement with the cellular operator allowing it to use ground telecommunications facilities. Centertel continues to use the equipment and TPSA is seeking hefty compensation for that.

Centertel, which is currently Poland's sole cellular phone company and uses an analogue system -- will soon face competition from two firms which have gained licences to set up modern GSM digital networks.
TPSA has blocked a bid by Centertel's foreign partners for a GSM licence.
